repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

physdesc.extent: 151 oversize boxes, 144 letter size document boxes, 23 record cartons, 1 half letter size document box, 1 half legal size document box, 1 poster tube, 2 oversized folders, and 2 volumes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into eight series. Series I consists of Correspondence, arranged by topic and then primarily chronological. Series II consists of Personal materials, including Murrow's family, his education, awards, publicity, personal correspondence, and papers related to his death. Series III consists of papers related to Murrow's professional life at the Institute of International Education, CBS, and USIA. Series IV contains Murrow's involvement in projects including his albums, publications, scripts, speeches, and in various clubs and organizations. Series V contains audio-visual materials from some of Murrow's radio broadcasts and television programs. Series VI consists of Murrow's memorabilia, including diaries, furnishings, honorary degrees and citations, and personal items. Series VII consists of the over 1,600 publications contained in Murrow's library, located in The Murrow Room. Series VIII contains audio-visual tributes to Edward R. Murrow. Series IX contains administrative files, reference requests and letters.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: On December 24, 1969, Mrs. Janet H. B. Murrow, widow of Edward R. Murrow, by grant of gift, transferred title to the books, papers, scripts, tapes, films, and memorabilia deposited with the Murrow Center, to The Edward R. Murrow Center of Public Diplomacy of The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University. These materials were Mr. Murrow's library and the file records of his professional career with some personal materials included.

This gift was accepted by the Murrow Center, subject to the following conditions: "It is my understanding that the Murrow Center will keep the aforementioned materials in the Murrow Center Library, will catalog them in the manner which will make them of maximum benefit in achieving the Center's objectives and will make them available - under appropriate regulations and in the Center's premises or library - to interested students. My son, Charles C. Murrow, and I wish to make sure that quotations and other uses of such materials in published works will reflect properly upon Mr. Murrow's memory and conform to the spirit in which this gift is being made. Therefore, during my life and during the life of my son, you shall not grant any publication rights in any of such materials (other than the right to quote short excerpts therefrom in scholarly works), unless such grant is approved by me, or if I am not living, by my son.

This gift is made subject to all rights, including common law and statutory copyright, which others may have in any of the aforementioned materials. It is also made subject to a certain agreement made as of March 16, 1966, between CBS News, a division of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and the Estate of Edward R. Murrow whereby CBS News retained exclusive broadcasting rights in certain of the aforementioned materials."
December 24, 1969 (Signed) Janet H. B. Murrow December 31, 1969 (Agreed to) Tufts University, C. Russell de Burlo, Jr.

Other donations were integrated into the collection while the materials were still at the Fletcher School; some donors are unknown. Known donors include Mary Marvin Breckinridge, Joseph E. Persico, and Edward Bliss.
This collection is open, but the Murrow estate, CBS, and other entities hold the copyright. For permissions, please contact the copyright holder.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was originally processed by Anne Sperber and Ginn Library staff at Fletcher in the 1970s. No processing documentation has survived.

Five 7" audio reels donated by Casey Murrow in 2011 (accession 2011.090) in containers labeled "Small World Severide," were found to be blank during digitization by George Blood, L.P. DCA staff double-checked the reels and confirmed that they were blank. The reels were confidentially destroyed.

On January 4, 2016 MS025.003.002.16.106.00351: Scripts was found to be not in the box by Rose Oliveira. Previous and subsequent boxes (Box 105 and 107) were checked but the folder was not found. Additional notes in collection documentation folder.

As part of a survey review in 2016, four boxes (MS025-003-MS025-006) of empty audio reel boxes for "This I Believe" were found in the green barcodes. This note was found in CIDER: "This item was found uncatalogued in the stacks. Tape boxes are kept as they have symbols we currently cannot identify, fall 2009." The tape boxes include the following numbers written on the exterior of the boxes: XTV16106, XTV16109-12, XTV16114-19, XTV16155, XTV161159, XTV17168-70, XTV17176, XTV18158, XTV18160, XTV18165, XTV18167, XTV18282, XTV18549, XTV1116097 XTV18560, XT18564, XTV19560, XTV19563-66, XTV19570, XTV19571, XTV20071- XTV20073, XTV20083, XTV20460, XTV20462, XTV20761- XTV20762, XTV20765, XTV21312-13, XTV21522, XTV21525, XTV21529. No associated audio reels were found and none appear to be in the collection. These empty boxes were removed from the collection and permanently destroyed. Rose Oliveira, March 28, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence, personal materials, work files, scripts, diaries, photographs, audiovisual materials, memorabilia, awards, books, clippings, and tributes to Murrow upon his death. Audiovisual materials include phonograph records, and film and audiotape reels of various formats. The bulk of the material dates from 1927 to 1965 and primarily documents the professional life of Edward R. Murrow. Through these materials one can trace major developments in the history of US news broadcasting, and Murrow's work for the Institute of International Education, CBS Europe and CBS USA as well as the United States Information Agency.

Correspondence comprises the bulk of Murrow's papers and includes the entire period of his career from 1930 to 1965. Please note that there is little correspondence for the period when he was Director of the United States Information Agency. Correspondence relates to historical and current issues; deal with key points and broadcasts in his career; cover problems of reporting and public diplomacy, radio and television - their role, their failures, their triumphs; reveal reactions to his work from viewers, celebrities, students, and how he handled criticism of his reporting and his view of his job; general interest items, including anecdotes, humorous letters, exchanges with close friends and well-known personalities; show something about the man, his non-involvement in politics, his concern over lack of public knowledge and interest in world affairs, his despair with television for not taking a stronger lead in educating people. Included are requests for appointments and invitations to speak, requests from charities and from friends for help in finding jobs and asking for personal advice, as well as inquiries pertaining to his programs and special events over the years.

Series 2 is devoted to personal matters - biographical material, family, college, chronological correspondence, awards, publicity, and Murrow's death. Murrow's professional employment, documented in Series 3, covers periods with the Institute of International Education, Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and the United States Information Agency. Subseries of each organization contain its own correspondence, reports, and related activities. In addition, the CBS subseries covers administration, program and business operations, correspondents, nine regularly scheduled programs as well as special programs, scripts and sponsors. This series records the history of radio and television broadcasting and as such has tremendous research value.

The collection reveals not only Murrow's demanding radio and television schedule but his extensive extra-curricular involvement with foundations, organizations and clubs; his production of albums, writings for publication, speeches; engagements accepted and engagements declined; and travels.

In addition to the papers, there are approximately 1,600 books shelved in the Murrow Memorial Room at the Fletcher School, along with Murrow memorabilia, mostly in facsimile. The oak table used by the Murrows in their London apartment during World War II, and two large black leather chairs and rug from their Pawling, New York home, can be found in the Murrow Memorial Room.

Tapes, films and phonograph records are stored in the Tufts Digital Collections and Archives at Tisch Library, to be used there by permission of the Murrow Center. CBS News is the donor of "File and Reference" prints of the two McCarthy 16mm films (March 9 and April 6, 1954) and the Murrow obituary film, "An Hour with Ed Murrow," and has agreed to donate additional Murrow films.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edward R. Murrow (1908-1965) was a prominent CBS broadcaster during the formative years of American radio and television news programs. Stationed in London for CBS Radio from 1937 to 1946, Murrow assembled a group of erudite correspondents who came to be known as the "Murrow Boys" and included one woman, Mary Marvin Breckinridge. Murrow's and their broadcasts from London, Europe, Africa, and Asia before and during World War II set the standard for US foreign news broadcasting. They also helped shape the public's view of a war that Americans were at first reluctant to be drawn into.

Returning to the US in 1946, Murrow became one of the most renowned radio and television news broadcasters of his time. Particularly famous were his programs Hear It Now, This I Believe, Person to Person, See It Now, and Years of Crisis. Of particular note are his 1954 broadcast about Senator Joseph McCarthy's persecution of presumed Communists and his 1960 Harvest of Shame documentary depicting the plight of migrant farm workers in the US. From 1961 to January 1964 he served as the Director of the United States Information Agency (USIA). Murrow died of cancer on April 27, 1965.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Quotations and permission to publish requests must be approved by the Murrow estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into seven parts.
001: General The general correspondence includes correspondence with admirers, personal friends, business associates, and prominent individuals such as Eleanor Roosevelt.
002: Applicants Correspondence with applicants include papers from individuals applying for employment with Murrow at CBS.
003: Books Correspondence relating to books contains files about books sent by publishers and authors to Murrow.
004: Engagements Accepted Correspondence regarding engagements accepted relates to speeches given by Murrow.
005: Engagements Declined There are also files relating to engagements declined by Murrow.
006: Special Events Some correspondence relates to special events and is arranged chronologically.
007: Special People Some correspondence relates to special people and is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The general correspondence includes correspondence with admirers, personal friends, business associates, and prominent individuals such as Eleanor Roosevelt. __The general correspondence files, 1945-1965, are arranged chronologically by year(s) groupings and then alphabetically by last or corporate name within each grouping. The incoming letters and outgoing replies for any particular individual or corporate name are arranged in reverse chronological order, with the most recent item appearing first.

The general correspondence includes both important and unimportant correspondence with admirers, personal friends, business associates, and individuals of recognized importance such as Eleanor Roosevelt and U. Nu. There is correspondence asking Murrow to endorse various products. He likewise received many invitations to speak, sign petitions, attend meetings, and join organizations or boards. Murrrow received many program suggestions, many of which are accompanied by supporting documentation.

Murrow's correspondence, 1961-63, as director of the United States Information Agency is maintained by the National Archives in Record Group 306. Some personal correspondence for this period is filed in Series 003.003.
There is little correspondence for 1964-65, when Murrow was ill. Those letters that were answered were handled by Mrs. Murrow.

did.unittitle: Edward R. Murrow at the Armed Forces Information School (Fort Slocum, NY.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Caption affixed to picture reads: "For Slocum, N.Y., June 28th -- Four Kappa Sigmas discussing military public information problems at the Armed Forces Information School here today after being introduced by Rear Admiral Thomas H. Binford, USN, school Commandant. Left to right: Admiral Binford; Edward R. Murrow, (Washington State '30); Seaman Apprentice Paxton Moore, USN (Washington and Lee '50); First Lieutenant Edward Wilcox, USMC, (Occidental '42); and Corporal Rhett Turnispeed, USA, (University of Georgia '50)."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This correspondence of 52 important individuals was probably taken from general correspondence (001.001) and grouped here alphabetically by last name, with correspondence, clipping, scripts and printed matter for each individual arranged in reverse chronological order. Included is correspondence from presidents, scientists, authors and others of importance with whom Murrow corresponded. Number 213 contains Xerox copies of important autograph letters which were taken from the collection and placed in the Edwin Ginn Library vault. A Xerox copy of each letter was also placed in its original file. Number 214 contains a small grouping of sensitive correspondence Murrow had with such personages as Theodore H. White, Louis Nizer, Vincent Sheean, J.G. Gude, Chet Huntley, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 15. Murrow did a radio program with Petr Zenkl. The book, Czechoslovakia - Under the Hammer and Sickle, by the Council of Free Czechoslovaka (Rada svobodneho Ceskoslovenska), 2nd ed. [1953?] was pulled from the Murrow Room Library because of preservation concerns. 5 documents found with book 'Hammer and Sickle' were also added to this folder, April 19 2011, Susanne Belovari. The five documents are: Petr Zenkl, The liberation of Eastern Europe by means short of war -- American Fund for Czechoslovak Rugees, inc., by-laws -- Council of Free Czechoslovakia, Press release : Czechoslovakia under the hammer and sickle (March 22, 1953) -- Council of Free Czechoslovakia, By what authority does the communist regime in Czechoslovakia bring its complaint of alleged subversive activities to the UN?(March 19, 1953) -- Memorandum of the Council of Free Czechoslovakia concerning a novel and cruel violation of human rights by the communist regime in Czechoslovakia (March 16, 1953).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 15

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains personal files on Murrow's biography and family life, personal correspondence from friends, professional associates, and fans, and personal publicity files with clippings and photographs of Murrow. Condolences and tributes received by Mrs. Murrow after Murrow's death are also included. Edward R. Murrow's personal files include a small amount of biographical data (215), data on members of the Murrow family (216-222), and information on Murrow's association with Washington State College, 1927-65 (223).

Of significance in this series is Murrow's personal correspondence, 1940-68, which is arranged in reverse chronological order. The correspondence concerns acknowledgements for gifts, letters from friends and professional associates, bills and receipts, fan mail from important people, correspondence regarding lawsuits, and correspondence regarding CBS. There is also correspondence, 1947-68, regarding awards and honors received by Murrow.
This series contains Murrow's personal publicity files, 1947-61, which include CBS press information, clippings about Murrow, and numerous photographs of Murrow.
Added to this series are the numerous tributes and condolences received by Mrs. Murrow in 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is also a positive photograph, and it is labeled on the back with "Edward R. Murrow covered the Korean war as a members of CBS' combat correspondents team. He reported directly from the war area, and preferred talking to soldiers, rather than officers. This photo was taken at Christmas 1952."

did.unittitle: Marian Anderson, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Edward R. Murrow upon receiving a 1958 specail award by The Fund for the Republic for the See it Now special 'The Lady from Philadelphia,'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is also a negative with same object id. Photograph is labeled on the back with "See It Now accompanied Marian Anderson, Black American contralto, on a tour of Asia. Murrow and Fred Friendly had to find a sponsor for the program themselves, because the CBS sales department had failed due to the shows presumed 'controversial' nature in the South. The program went on to receive several recognitions." The 1957 program was partially funded by the USIA, as one of its programs using minority artists to bolster the international image of the US.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Edward R. Murrow's professional files from the institutions at which he was employed between 1934 and 65. The series is divided into three subseries:
001: Institute for International Education 002: Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. 003: United States Information Agency

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Murrow served the Institute in a number of capacities, but most notably as a member of the Executive Committee and the Board of Trustees. This section includes his correspondence, filed in reverse chronological order, with the Institute staff members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 20

scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of Murrow's professional life at CBS. The subseries is further segmented into 23 sections and consists of correspondence with CBS colleagues, CBS administrative memos and reports, fan mail, program scripts, background research, and publicity. Of particular interest in this series are the McCarthy files accumulated by CBS around the time of Murrow's "See It Now" episode on McCarthy (March 9, 1954).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section primarily includes Murrow's correspondence with fourteen CBS employees. These files obviously represent only the personal and job related correspondence which Murrow decided to retain for himself. There is actually very little correspondence (less than half a folder) for each individual, with the exception of Frank Stanton. The correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This one file folder includes congratulatory letters Murrow received when he joined CBS Board of Directors in 1949, and subsequent correspondence, memoranda, and reports he received as a Board Member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

did.unittitle: CBS - consultative, news and public affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder of correspondence, memoranda, and reports deals with CBS programs and policies in which Murrow was involved or was consulted on by other CBS officials. One of the issues involved setting up guidelines for television news editorials. This file is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section contains Murrow's correspondents, including Charles Collingwood, Richard Hottelet, Daniel Schorr, Eric Sevareid, and Howard K. Smith. The correspondence for each news correspondent is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder of inter-office communications (memoranda) relates primarily to various CBS department operations. This material is arranged in reverse chronogical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This one folder of fan mail relates to Murrow's return to broadcasting. The correspondence is arranged in reverse chronogical order.

scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder of inter-office communications relates primarily to memoranda sent directly to or by Murrow. The material is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains correspondence, but primarily copies of cables between CBS' New York and London offices. Howard K. Smith figures prominently in the correspondence, while he serves as European Director stationed in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A folder of inter-office communications (memoranda) which relate primarily to the management of Murrow's CBS office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section contains two folders of company communications (primarily memoranda) relating directly to company policy. Included are copies of Tie-Line, a serial report of the Employee-Management Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 22

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section is divided into three parts: program operations, advertising agencies, and sponsors. The program operations folders contain correspondence, memoranda, and reports about various radio and television programs conducted or considered by Murrow. Folder number 322 provides lists prepared by Palmer Williams in 1973 of Murrow's radio and television broadcasts. The correspondence, memoranda, photographs, and reports in the files for advertising agencies and sponsors relates to Murrow's relationship with the agencies' personnel and the sponsors for various broadcasts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section contains a complete set of the scripts for Background, a radio program which ran from July 1960 to February 1961. Also included is fan mail, business correspondence, lists of participants, and drafts of the scripts, many showing holographic changes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section includes scripts, correspondence, memoranda, reports, and news clippings for 5 programs of this 23-part television program which ran from October 27, 1959 to February 16, 1961. Also included is a script for "Operation Crossroads - Africa," which was never aired, and an April 30, 1965 special tribute entitled, "An Hour With Ed Murrow."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 23

did.unittitle: CBS - Programs - Edward R. Murrow with the News

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is a fairly complete collection of scripts for "Edward R. Murrow With the News," Sept. 26, 1947 - June 26, 1959, with which he closed the broadcast. Missing from the collection are the following scripts: 1948: June 8-11, 14-18, 22, 24, 28-30; July; October 1, 8. 1949: July 4, 5, 7, 8, 11-31; August 1-28. 1950: April 6, July 10, 12-14, 17-21, 26-28, 31; August 15, 17, 21-25, 28-31; September. 1951: January 29-31; February 1, 2; July; August 1-24. 1952: July 24; August 4-31. 1953: July; August; September 1-11. 1954: January 4; July 5, 7, 8, 13-16, 19, 21-23, 26, 27, 29, 30; August 2-4, 6, 9-12, 17-20, 23, 25-27. 1955: July 2-31; August 1-28. 1956: July; August 1-8, 20-23, 27-31; September 1-7, 11, 13-30; October 1-5. 1957: July; August. 1958: June 30; July 22, 23.

The scripts are arranged in chronological order. For each broadcast, there is usually the official typescript of the broadcast and a copy of the broadcast, usually annotated, as delivered by Murrow. There are textual variations in these two scripts for each broadcast. Also included are special scripts, 1947; scripts for presidential candidate interviews, 1948; and scripts for special broadcasts, 1952-56.

This section also contains correspondence, 1947-57, regarding reprint requests; fan mail statistical summaries, 1948-59; and lists of payments to correspondents and others who participated in the broadcasts, 1947-50.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Section 17 includes correspondence, scripts and correspondence for special programs, and similar materials and reference files for Murrow's programs on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in 1954. The correspondence, 1951-58, is arranged alphabetically by year and concerns the production of See It Now and viewers' reactions.

There are approximately 70 special programs represented in this section. The programs are arranged chronologically, 1951-58, by date of presentation. This title and date of each program is provided, as well as an indication of the contents of each file. An asterisk(*) following the date indicates the file contains just correspondence about the program. Two asterisks(**) indicates the file contains both correspondence abut he script. A lack of an asterisk indicates that only the script is available for the program.

The material relating to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is voluminous. Included is correspondence and scripts for the Murrow show of March 9, 1954, McCarthy's reply of April 6, and Murrow's subsequent statement of April 6. There is correspondence arranged alphabetically, congratulating Murrow for his stand on the McCarthy issue, as well as telegrams, and news clippings about the program.

Filed under the heading, Matter of "M", is a reference file established by CBS researchers as a result of the McCarthy program. CBS assumed that McCarthy's broadcast of April 6 involved an attack on Murrow and the network with a demand that they should be investigated by a Congressional Committee. These files were prepared to answer any eventual charges.

There is a large volume of abstracts of information on Murrow and McCarthy which is coded with roman numerals I-III. Those coded I relate to Murrow, those coded II relate to McCarthy, while those III relate to CBS. The abstracts, by means of the code system, are related to the original source documents which are also in this section. These reference files contain correspondence, memoranda, printed matter, news clippings, and several scripts, some for Person to Person. __Research Staff Members: E.C. Perkins, D.H. Rivkin, R. Sloane, J.H. Pickering, J.E. Ryder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Microfilm Reel 42. For added memorandum (4/20/1954 from D.H. Rivkin), see MS025/006.007 1:5 (barcode: 39090011518475). See "Memorandum" enclosed - "This memorandum is based on the assumption that McCarthy's broadcast on April 6, 1954 involves an attack on Ed Murrow or the networks with the demand that they should be investigated by a Congressional Committee, presumably his own. It is, of course, important to be prepared to identify them as a reprisal at the first available opportunity. One way this could be done would be to show a pattern of conduct by McCarthy in attacking, as a reprisal, any person who, in the exercise of his independent judgement, dares publicly to disagree with him or criticize him. ---." (unsigned) One complete set, one incomplete duplicate set."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section contains files for forty special programs, mostly aired over CBS, with which Murrow was involved in some manner. The files vary as to contents, the most complete containing correspondence, memoranda, newsclippings, and scripts. Some files just contain a synopsis of the program or a script.

scopecontent.p: Murrow's files as director of the United States Information Agency are housed in the National Archives, Washington, D.C. The small amount of material contained here represents copies of Murrow's statement before the Senate confirmation hearing, copies of his reports and speeches, and his personal correspondence as director.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incomplete files for five of Murrow's Albums constitute this part. Those files for "I Can Hear It Now" and "Sir Winston Churchill" are the most complete and contain correspondence, memoranda, financial records, newsclippings and promotional material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This part contains the files for 35 organizations with which Murrow was associated, either as a participant, member, or as an officer or member of the board of directors. The organizations are arranged in alphabetical order by title, with material in each file arranged in reverse chronological order. The types and quantity of material for each organization varies, but usually correspondence, memoranda, newsclippings, press releases, minutes, speeches, and printed matter are available. A listing of the organizations, with inclusive dates of the correspondence for each, is provided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The speech files usually contain one or more drafts of a speech, the finished speech, and correspondence and clippings relating to the speech. Of particular note are Murrow's 1959 Granada Lecture, his speeches for the United States Information Agency, and a compilation (number 566) of his noteworthy speeches, 1941-61.

(02/08/1963) Remarks at the dedication of the Voice of America's Relay Station, Greenville, NC; (02/11/1963) Address at the 23rd Annual Distinguished Service Award Banquet, Kinston Junior Chamber of Commerce, Kinston, NC; (03/05/1963) Statement before the Subcommittee on Foreign Affairs House of Representatives; (03/28/1963) Statement before the Subcommittee on International Organizations and Movements of the Committee on Foreign Affairs House of Representatives; (04/05/1963) Statement before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in support of The National Academy of Foreign Affairs (NAFA); (06/09/1963) Address at the East Carolina College Commencement, Greenville, NC; (06/14/1963) Extract from an address before the 72nd Annual Convention, General Federation of Women's Clubs, Milwaukee, WI; (06/19/1963) Address before 59th Annual Convention, Advertising Federation of America, Atlanta, GA; (07/01/1963) Address before National Education Association, Detroit, MI; (09/1963) Address at USIA's 7th Annual Honor Awards Ceremony; (09/26/1963) Address before the National Convention of the Federal Bar Association, Philadelphia, PA (Murrow last speech).

did.unittitle: Q&A session following "In Honor of a Man and an Ideal" speech

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original housing reads: Edward R. Murrow Q&A session following speech upon his return to U.S. from Europe 12-2:1941 (5 days before Pearl Harbor). Speech is not on this tape - only Q&A followed by Kate Smith singing "God Bless America." Running time 34:41. Unidentified location.

This Q&A session covers topics that include: whether the British Government is justified in refusing to undertake an offensive in Western Europe; Rudolph Hess; the "Far East situation"; British worries about hostile actions from the French Fleet; whether contagious disease is a problem in England; covering London via broadcast news versus cable service; the Churchill government; the food crisis in England; the British campaign in Libya; British and German intelligence; attitude of the British public toward American reluctance to send troops into Europe; the strength of the Soviet Union; Clarence Streit's Union Now proposal; and Ambassador John Winant and American diplomatic representation in London.
More material regarding "In Honor of a Man and an Ideal" in MS025.004.005.132.00566

did.unittitle: "Wires and Lights" speech to Radio and Television News Directors Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this speech to the Radio and Television News Directors Association, Murrow voices concerns regarding the impact of advertising on radio and television broadcasting.
More material regarding Murrow's speech to the RTNDA in MS025.004.005.132.00563

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Murrow's audio-visual records. The series is arranged by topic/media type into 13 subseries. The bulk of this material consists of audiotape reels (10" and 7" reels), with some film reels, video, and phonograph records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section contains 26 phonograph records, the majority of which Murrow was involved in. Highlights of this series include Murrow's "I Can Hear It Now," "Edward R. Murrow, A Reporter Remembers," and a 1949 Murrow audition.

did.unittitle: Album cover - "I Can Hear It Now" Edward R. Murrow, 1919-1949, 30 Years of Audible History. Delux Edition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Narrator - Edward R. Murrow. Producers - Murrow, Friendly, Gude. Columbia Records Inc. Some of the recordings include: Wilson and the League; Harding and Teapot Dome; Sacco and Vanzetti; The Stock Market Crash; Roosevelt and the Depression; Chamberlain at Munich; The Nazi Blitzkrieg; Churchill and Coalition; Pearl Harbor; D-Day Invasion; VE Day and VJ Day Celebrations; Nuremberg War Trials; Assassination of Gandhi; The Birth of Israel; The Berlin Airlift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 copies. Narrative announcements by Douglas Edwards. Prepared and edited by Fred W. Friendly, Alvin Snyder and Sheldon Hoffman. Broadcasts by Edward R. Murrow. Produced by Columbia Records/CBS Inc.

did.unittitle: Edward R. Murrow, a Reporter Remembers. Volume One: The War Years. Record 1 of 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 copies. Side 1: February 24, 1946 - "A Reporter Remembers" - London; August 31, 1939 - "Churchill evacuated from London; September 3, 1939 - Britain declares war; September 4, 1939 - First air raids; November 27, 1939 - Air raid warning system; April 9, 1940 - Debate in Parliament; May 8, 1940 - Chamberlain asked to resign; May 10, 1940 - Winston Churchill becomes Prime Minister; June 2, 1940 - Dunkirk. Side 2: June 4, 1940 - Churchill talks about Dunkirk; August 24, 1940 - Trafalgar Square air raid; August 25, 1940 - Reaction to bombings; September 22, 1940 - On rooftop during air raid; September 29, 1940 - Visit to West Somerset; December 2, 1940 - Courage of British; December 24, 1940 - Christmas.

did.unittitle: Edward R. Murrow, a Reporter Remembers. Volume One: The War Years. Record 2 of 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 copies. Side 3: March 9, 1941 - Spring in England; November 7, 1942 - African campaign; December 24, 1942 - Yanks at Christmas; December 3, 1943 - Berlin raid. Side 4: June 6, 1944 - D-Day; September 17, 1944 - Arnhem drop; April 1945 - The Return to Germany; April 15, 1945 - Buchenwald; May 8, 1945 - Piccadilly -- VE-Day; February 24, 1946 - "A Reporter Remembers" - London.

did.unittitle: Album cover - Edward R. Murrow, a Reporter Remembers. Volume Two: 1948-1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Introduction and Accompanying Narration by Charles Collingwood. Prepared and edited by Edward Bliss, Jr. Technical Editor, Fred H. Turner. Broadcasts by Edward R. Murrow. Produced by Columbia Records/CBS Inc.

did.unittitle: Edward R. Murrow, a Reporter Remembers. Volume Two: 1948-1961. Record 1 of 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Side 1: Introduction - Charles Collingwood; September 20, 1948 - Berlin Blockade; November 3, 1948 - Truman Elected; June 2, 1949 - Alger Hiss Trial; June 9, 1949 - The Right to Dissent; March 8, 1950 - Some of the News; August 1, 1950 - "This Is Korea." Side 2: August 8, 1950 - Day with the 1st Calvary Division; September 6, 1950 - Testing Ground for Ideas; October 12, 1950 - D.A.R. -- Fort Knox Gold; October 12, 1950 - Exclusion of Communists; September 3, 1951 - Labor Day Speeches; April 17, 1952 - Missouri River Flood; June 4, 1952 - Eisenhower's First Campaign Speech; November 26, 1953 - Reasons for National Thanksgiving; March 9, 1954 - Summation, Broadcast on Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy.

did.unittitle: Edward R. Murrow, a Reporter Remembers. Volume Two: 1948-1961. Record 2 of 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Side 3: March 18, 1954 - Supreme Court on School Segregation; September 9, 1954 - Hurricane Edna; October 5, 1954 - Murrow and Sandburg; April 12, 1955 - Salk Vaccine; May 4, 1955 - Vietnam Crisis; October 26, 1955 - The Vice Presidency; November 28, 1955 - Cross-Channel Flight. Side 4: February 13, 1956 - Racial Issue in '56 Campaign; April 30, 1956 - Death of Alban Barkley; November 6, 1956 - End of the Israeli-Egyptian War; February 4, 1957 - Moral Force of the United Nations; September 23, 1958 - Modernizing the Presidency; July 3, 1960 - U.S. Role in the World; January 22, 1961 - John F. Kennedy's Inauguration.

did.unittitle: William M. Mandel's McCarthy Committee Hearing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written on side 1 of LP "(author) 'This is a bookburning! You lack only the tinder to set fire to the books as Hitler did twenty years ago, and I am going to get that across to the American people!". Written on side 2: "You, Senator McCarthy, murdered Maj. Raymond Kaplan by driving him to the point where he jumped under a truck, although everybody knows that there was nothing that could have merited even the most unimportant punishment for that man."

scopecontent.p: Description of "After the Battle" footage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 127 10" audiotape reels of the program "This I Believe," organized chronologically by the original identification number (XTV).

did.unittitle: Introduction to the Original "This I Believe" Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edward R. Murrow introduces This I Believe to the audience and describes its purpose.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Julien Bryan describes his early religious beliefs and the transformation, as a result of his experiences in WWI and filmaking, that led him to his belief in the common goodness of all people around the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Justice Douglas explains his father's last words and why faith, like his father's, is necessary to ensure freedom and guide people and nations through difficult times.

did.unittitle: Closer Than My Own Back Yard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bill Sears talks about his belief in the importance of developing faith and a moral character to live life to its fullest potential and greatest happiness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lee Bristol describes his belief in the individual, the individual's role in achieving peace and acquiring happiness through humor, service to others, and faith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carroll Binder relates his personal tragedies and the principles he relies on to avoid cynicism and maintain the enjoyment of life through adversity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Constance Warren discusses the importance of education to happiness and ethics and describes the values that have made her life a happy one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edward Morgan talks about the importance of underastanding one's self and compassion for humanity to achieving a greater understanding and appreciation of life and beauty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Norman Cousins elaborates on the play of free will and determinism in the development of people and society and the detrimental affects fear can have on this development.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Susan Savage talks about the impact the death of her mother had on her and her beliefs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job #113067. "Side I" written on reel.

did.unittitle: The Only Way to Make a Friend

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senator Lehman describes his two basic beliefs: First, one should give back to society according to what he or she has received, and secondly, one should extend respect to the opinions and beliefs of others.

did.unittitle: The Light of a Brighter Day

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Helen Keller describes her faith in God, in immortality, and in her fellow human beings, as well as her confidence that social conditions are improving, despite the present sufferings of humanity. Helen Keller describes her faith in God, in immortality, and in her fellow human beings, as well as her confidence that social conditions are improving, despite the present sufferings of humanity. Helen Keller describes her faith in God, in immortality, and in her fellow human beings, as well as her confidence that social conditions are improving, despite the present sufferings of humanity. Helen Keller describes her faith in God, in immortality, and in her fellow human beings, as well as her confidence that social conditions are improving, despite the present sufferings of humanity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job #113067. Written on reel: "11' 13 1/45" and "Haydn" and "Sonata #30, Sonata #24"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harry Overstreet describes how Socrates has influenced his thinking, leading to the beliefs that truth must be sought out (rather than accepted) and that knowledge about the world can never be exhausted, and forming the foundation for his tolerant acceptance of his fellow human beings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Col. Ralph K. Strassman describes his belief in the importance of human beings, and the enduring persistence of human personality, despite the failures and fears of the present age.

did.unittitle: The Proud People of a Proud Country

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: James B. Carey describes his belief in liberty for all humanity, based on his belief that all Americans are "displaced persons" (immigrants) and have the right to pursue the resources necessary to fulfill their basic physical and spiritual needs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anne Phipps describes her ongoing transition from a belief simply in outward things--such as the beauty to be found in nature, art, dance and literature--to a belief in her inner soul.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Howard Henderson describes how a series of failures and challenges during his early life and career revealed to him an inner strength and resiliance, and describes his belief that a person's strength comes from being part of a greater whole - family, community, world, or God.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gilbert F. White describes his experiences as a geographer and student of earth's natural laws, and his belief that the divine spark within every person necessitates brotherhood, tolerance, humble service, and a commitment to search for truth.

did.unittitle: I Call Things As I See Them

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ralph "Babe" Pinelli describes his beliefs in the importance of God, a strong marriage and family, religious training that starts in the home, a country that supports freedom of conscience, and baseball.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eleanor Roosevelt describes growing up in a religious household and later questioning her childhood beliefs, and concludes with the belief that a person must simply do the best that she can while meeting the future with courage.

did.unittitle: Looking At Life Through Another's Eyes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Johnson describes how his great-grandfather's experience with slavery, his father's experience as a Baptist minister, and his own college experience in social services have helped to shape his belief that "no man can be justly judged until youve looked at the world through his eyes".

did.unittitle: What Does God Say to Me?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edith Evans describes how she believes that good is stronger than evil, that following Christ's command to love God and one's neighbors will bring about a better world, and that fear of war and social chaos can be answered by relying on the power of good to overcome.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Howard Petersen describes how children confidently believe that good will triumph over evil, and outlines his belief that we must work to make this youthful optimism a reality by learning to live in harmony with others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: E.W. Ziebarth describes being challenged in high school to write out his beliefs and finds that, years later, his beliefs are just as difficult to pin down; nevertheless, he firmly believes in freedom, the worth and dignity of the individual, and the need to receive generalizations and proproganda with a healthy dose of skepticism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: J. George Frederick uses the analogy of the heart's cardiovascular system to describe his beliefs in the need to love, to forgive, and to sacrifice for others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job #113104. Written on reel: "Reel IV 12:12, plus?. #5 NRW". No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job #113132. "Reel #2" "B-" written on reel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Judge Millen describes how, despite his experience as a judge with the bad side of people, he still maintains an optimistic belief in the overall goodness of people, and while he still becomes discouraged and impatient with prejudice, his religion gives him comfort and support.

did.unittitle: A Straight Wall is Hard to Build

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lou Crandall describes his belief that hard work brings value to our accomplishments, a belief he believes that his ancestors, the founding fathers, and architects and engineers from history all shared.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Hubben describes how, despite his experiences in Nazi Germany and the popular lack of faith in social progress, he still maintains a belief in the meaning of life and faith in the moral values of the next generation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kenneth Johnson talks of the importance of democracy, freedom and human welfare, and emphasizes the ethical principles that underlie our democratic ideals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edward Mann describes the simple truths that he believes are the root of his happines; faith in God, service to others, and friendships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henderson Suplee talks about the importance of opportunity in life and achieving harmony.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arthur Hays speaks about his belief in freedom and the importance of democratic values and ideals to maintaining liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Curtin Winsor tells of the importance of individualism and being true to himself in the development of his beliefs and what some of those beliefs are.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job #113843. "Reel #4" written on reel. Includes incomplete clip from essay by Caroline Duer (essay not included).

did.unittitle: The Fun of Chasing a Goal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Douglas Fairbanks describes his fathers resistance to his acting career, and difficulties starting his political carreer and how he overcame obstacles through his determination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hudson Hoagland describes the importance of science and democracy and how they work together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clair Bee talks about some of his experiences and hardships coaching and working with youth and the faith in youth that has developed from these experiences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job #113843. "#2 Ann" and "Master #4" written on reel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimitri Mitropolous describes two experiences, that led him to his belief that talent and celebrity should be used to help others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Hughes talks about living honestly as a taxicab driver in New York City.

controlaccess.subject: Character
Ethics
Fortitude
Golden rule
New York (N.Y.) - Social life and customs
Taxicab drivers
Work

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elmer Davis discusses the importance of intellectual freedom to freedom and progress, and some of the difficulties that can come with such freedom.

did.unittitle: We Can't Just Play with Spools

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General Hershey laments society's fascination with technological progress and opines that society would be better off if people focused on understanding themselves, others around them and their relationships with one another.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Margaret Hickey recalls her childhood when her father read the Bible to the famiy, and describes how her faith must be an active one of service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Walden Pell describes his belief that life is an "educational enterprise" filled with teachers who must be sure that they are passing along the truth to the next generation.

did.unittitle: A Haven Beside the Still Waters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gene Harris describes his belief that following "natural laws" in one's daily life will help build a "storm-proof philosophic anchorage."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ralph Besse explains that he believes in God because it is the only explanation that makes sense of the world to him, and states that it is important to know God personally and work toward achieving God's purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#115569. No date is available for this reel.

did.unittitle: To Face Eternity with a Smile

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paul Helms describes his work with the Ford Foundation, as well as the impact his Christian upbringing has had on his beliefs, including his belief that giving 10% of his income results in tangible blessings.

scopecontent.p: Neal Brewster uses the Parable of the Talents to describe his belief that he must live his life to the fullest, pursuing friendships rather than material wealth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ralph Waldo Gerard describes his belief in the power of truth to free men from disease, prejudice, and other ills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lee DuBridge describes his beliefs in science, both what can be understood now, and what will be explained as civilization progresses toward the future.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles McGaha describes his belief that he is responsible to help make the world a better place, and explains how his belief that circumstances can impact a person's outcome in life gives him more tolerance of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#115853. "G Major" is written on reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Heinlein talks about his beliefs in his neighbors--in their kindness and willingness to look out for each other, despite differences in opinions or creeeds. NOTE: This version has been abbreviated to include an advertisement after the essay. Contains advertisement for a book containing 100 "This I Believe" essays. Duplicate of the essay, complete and without the advertisement, is on XTV-18161 (Box 004).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sidonie Gruenberg describes her belief in the importance of both family life and productive occupation outside the home, and recounts how she balanced those beliefs in her own life. NOTE: This version has been abbreviated to include an advertisement after the essay. Contains advertisement for a book containing 100 "This I Believe" essays. Duplicate of the essay, complete and without the advertisement, is on XTV-18161 (Box 004).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asa Call describes his beliefs in moral and spiritual laws that, like the physical laws of nature, must be discovered and adhered to for a successful life. NOTE: This version has been abbreviated to include an advertisement after the essay. Contains advertisement for a book containing 100 "This I Believe" essays. Duplicate of the essay, complete and without the advertisement, is on XTV-18161 (Box 004).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Dobie describes his belief in those things that make him "feel big": he believes in a supreme Being, the value of questioning to avoid blind faith, and the importance of eliminating prejudice. NOTE: This version has an abbreviated introduction, to make room to include an advertisement after the essay. Contains advertisement for a book containing 100 "This I Believe" essays. Duplicate of the essay, complete and without the advertisement, is on XTV-21312 (Box 016).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: W.C. Mullendore describes his belief that "we are here to develop the best that is within us," and how hatred impedes that goal. NOTE: This version has been abbreviated to include an advertisement after the essay. Contains advertisement for a book containing 100 "This I Believe" essays. Duplicate of the essay, complete and without the advertisement, is on XTV-18162 (Box 004).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116096. "#4" written on box, "Out 1" written on reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lillian Ferrence describes a moment of spiritual revelation in the sculpture court at the Brooklyn Museum, and her beliefs in God's tie to beauty, the importance of considering the feelings of others, the use of humor to dispel anxiety, and the brotherhood of humanity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Weil describes his beliefs that one must earn future privileges through the work of today, that belief in the future provides strength for meeting the challenges of today, and that people in general have the wisdom and integrity to achieve a better tomorrow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lily Pons describes how she learned to deal with stage fright, and how an inner voice helped her persevere to become an opera singer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116096. Written on box "1,3,4". Written on reel but crossed off "Joan of Arc Prologue"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dale Brown describes his belief that he must repay the debt he owes to his community through service to others in the community, as well as his belief that we must strive for tolerance, limiting anger and listening to others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Louis MacNeice defines beliefs as statements of personal preference, and describes his belief that the world can avoid anarchism because people share many of the same preferences, including the desire to build an orderly society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Guy West recounts how he first became aware of the immense size of the universe, and describes his beliefs in a God who designed and provides purpose for that universe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Howard McKinney describes growing up in an urban city (Pittsburgh) and explains that, because of the influence of a Sunday School teacher he directed his life away from crime, he feels compelled to offer similar opportunities to Pittsburgh's youth today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: President Hoover describes the importance of religious faith in life, science, and politics. A duplicate of this essay is on reel XTV-16923 (Box 002).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Benjamin Thomas describes how his study of Abraham Lincoln helped him believe that there is a universal struggle between good and evil, and that acknowledging our own imperfections helps us to be tolerant of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas O Leary describes stories of human kindness, and his belief that working in newspapers is a way to bring the truth to light.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Danforth describes how, when he was a sickly farm boy, his school teacher challenged him to live healthily; from that, Danforth developed a life philosophy to stand tall (through exercise and healthy eating habits), think tall (through education), smile tall (through friendliness and kindness) and live tall (through character development).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116096. "2,3,4" written on box. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: P. K. Menzies describes his belief in the physician's responsibility to treat his patients with respect and dignity, and explains how his study of the intricate workings of the human body formed his belief that the universe must have been designed by a "supreme architect."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lucile Watson recounts her childhood discovery of the knowledge that she could change herself for the better, and, after successes with simple things such as maintaining her hair and quitting nail-biting, she developed a philosophy for life, including a belief that God was in everything and made everything.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moekarto Notowidigdo, Foreign Minister of the Republic of Indonesia, describes being in jail during the Indonesian push for independence, and witnessing the comraderie of prisoners from all socioeconomic statuses, which led them to sing the Indonesian National Anthem during an execution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Levy, Deputy District Attorney of Contra Costa County in California, describes how he learned level-headed contentment in order to survive as a POW on the Death March of Bataan during WWII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116096. "French tape, side 2" written on back of box. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Tucker describes his belief in honesty and keeping one's word, and recounts how he strives to teach his son that even so-called "white lies" still hurt the teller of the lie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nobel Prize winning President of the Royal Academy, Henry Dale describes his belief in the "supreme value of truth" and the need for science to join forces with religion to help explain both material reality and our immaterial feelings of free will and a moral purpose in life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Constance Spry describes how she adopted her father's love of truth, justice, beauty, and poetry, and explains her father's practice of listening to, rather than judging, the beliefs and opinions of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wallace Stegner describes his suspicions of "passionate faith" because of the religious intolerance it creates, and recounts his beliefs in virtues such as kindness and courage, and his belief that although consciences are developed differently, based on one's birthplace, nevertheless, people across the world share many values.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116097. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Claude Fuess, Headmaster of Phillips Academy, describes himself as a "long-range optimist" who believes that the majority of today's boys are full of character and thoughtfulness, despite the newspaper headlines that suggest the moral decline of youth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carr Liggett describes his belief that Jesus' Gospel is the way to happiness, and his uncertainities regarding the faith of his parents, as well as his beliefs in the importance of freedom, in accepting life and the world as we find it, and in tolerating and understanding others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fannie Hurst talks about the example her husband set of how to live a selfless life, and her belief that many such lights of selfless living--though small--can together illuminate an entire arena in the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Viscount Simon describes his belief that life is like a train which must come to an end at some point during the journey, but we should not view life with dread, even if he does not believe in an afterlife.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116097. "1,2,3" written on reel. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Emery Tobin, Editor and Founder of the Alaska Sportsman, describes his belief that people have been placed in a beautiful creation in order to work to improve themselves and to serve others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sol Hurok recounts his experiences as an immigrant to America, and his vision for a venture that would bring classical artists to a popular audience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Norman Katkov describes his belief in the internal struggle between good and evil and his belief that conscience will help a person to overcome that evil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Theodore Roosevelt III describes what he believes was an unusual family life growing up--his father ensured he spent time with the children--and describes his own belief in and appreciation for the support of his wife and the value of a strong home life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116097. "1,2,3" written on reel. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eliza Thayer observes how fortunate she has been in life to underscore her beliefs in the importance of love in one's life and why love assures her in the existence of life after death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Steuart Wilson describes the search for truth and why a love for the truth must also be accompanied by the will to act on deeply felt convictions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John McKeen explains why beliefs are important and expresses his faith in the ultimate goodness of people, the intimate connection between the spiritual and the material, the drive to live, and the responsibility to safeguard the welfare of others and not only ourselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Verona Slater describes her experience with religion as a child, the daughter of a minister, and how her beliefs in wisdom, kindess, courage and strneght have been shaped by these experiences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116097. "Save Reel 1" "WSC" "Save RI - Rev" written on reel. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Taft talks about God's love and the necessity to strive to be worthy of his love but understanding one's imperfections as well, and how he tries to connect the sublime with the more practical aspects of life through hard work and introspection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Woodcock describes the expereinces he had growing up that led him to the belief in fairness and justice and also propelled him towards involvemnt in the labor movement.

did.unittitle: Work Is the Sweetening of Life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Katherine Bottigheimer remembers an encounter with her elderly cousin Theresa and the consequent philosophy she unconsciously developed as a result: the value of hard work for the betterment of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joseph Weinreb reflects on ethics and morality and resolves that nothing is created bad or evil but becomes so Joseph Weinrab reflects on ethics and morality and resolves that nothing is created bad or evil but becomes so misdirection and love, compassion, and hard work are means by which we can achieve a harmonious world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116098. No date is available for this reel.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Hailsham of St. Marylebone, Quintin Hogg, Baron

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Viscount Halisham considers and rejects the idea of materialism and embraces an immaterial universe at the center of which is Jesus Christ who can redeem the suffering and sins of mankind.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Percy explains why believes he has never met a person he did not respect, because he is open to listening and seeing who they truly are beneath the surface.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lucrezia Kemper describes how her family taught her the foundation of her beliefs and success; the value of faith in people, respect for others, kindness and generosity and security.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert McEwen describes his faith in people that he developed from working with young people in education and his belief in the adaptability of people in a dynamic universe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116098. "Incomplete Bl. Out" written on box. "1-2-3-4 5,6 8" written on reel. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harry Levenson relates his experience as a musician to the struggles of people in the world and explains his belief that doing ones best and appreciating the the individual as a perosn can guide us towards a peaceful future.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Pillsbury describes how she developed faith and belief in God and also her belief in the goodness of people and that we each have abilites they have been given to us for a purpose.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Boothby discusses the incomprehensibility of life and the Universe and describes his efforts to improve society and life through politics and economics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lewis Stevens discusses the importance of the spirit, affection and faith in God's love to withstand the trials and calamity of the material world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116098. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Julius Bixler explores the tension between faith and reason and explains why skepticism falls short in comparrison to faith and experiences like love, friendship, family and the goodness of people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gerald Heard describes his perspectives on moral laws and the freedoms we must obtain to achieve true contentment in our life, free of fears and anxiety.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Palmer describes the environment in which she grew up and the values and faith she acquired as a result, and why this faith might help others navigate through a confusing and "unpredictable era."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116098. "TIB Reel 2-A" written on box, "2,4,5,6 8-3" written on reel. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Doris Almy explains how her trust in the omnipotence of God and the reestablishment of her faith allowed her to overcome her fears and anxiety, and discusses her belief in kindness and education as a relief from anxiety in the lives of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Karl Nottingham explains our duty to adjust to society and some ways to do so such as; observing the Golden Rule, treating others with kindness, and helping those less fortunate, earning trust through friendship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Cornelius describes the two sayings that have stayed with him, "All things are great and small by comparison" and "service is the rent we pay for the space we occupy," and concludes by emphasizing the importance of supporting and educating youth to fight Communism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: E. E. Wieman explains the importance of sharing in life and how sharing is exemplified in sports; however, Wieman also describes how learned to share from his mother, which is the basis of his optimism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank La Forge describes his work and achievements in his career as a musician and pianist and believes in the necessity of acting to the best of one's ability and faith in God's support of one's efforts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#-. "NRW" written on reel. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Lester explains the importance of education and sports in teaching children to be good and remembers the advice of his mentor John Meggs, that he must love his students if he is to teach them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Samuel Guard tells the story of a young boy becoming an excellent farmer through dedication and faith in hinself, a capability that Samuel Guard says lies within everyone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Schoenbrun talks about his introduction to Descartes and Philosophy; the importance of doubting and questioning to liberty and his life; and how, contrary to assumption, his doubt is based on and strengthens his faith and spirituality.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Amy Vanderbilt explains her awareness and appreciation of people, equality and friendship and describes how her son exemplified this in his disregard for race when meeting a lady on the bus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#117546. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kenneth Boulding explains that as a quaker and an economist he understands that pure scientific knowledge is important but meaningless if unaccompanied by an appreciation for the intuitive and spiritual side of life, which he experiecnes through prayer and contemplation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Art Linkletter talks about his experiences in the entertainment industry as a host and announcer and how his focus on his own abilities, limits and performance, as well as his appreication of people, has contributed to his success.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edina Campbell Dover discusses her guiding philosophy to behave in the same manner as she imagines Jesus Christ would, and the outcomes of this philosophy in her life and work and also explains the need for prayer, and its importance, on a frequent and regular basis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#117549. "Reel #2" "6-5-4 7-3 8" "NRW" written on reel.

scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#-. Written on reel: "out" . Includes incomplete clip from essay by Hector Bolitho (essay not included). No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.p: Hans Simons remembers his experiences in Nazi, Germany and the necessity of leaving Europe and tells how he assimilated and appreciates the diversity and freedoms of his new country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rose Resnick describes her experiences as a blind pianist trying to make a living and the depression she found herself in. At the suggestion of a friend she turned to prayer and describes the transformation this suggestion had on her life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carl Carmer remembers the education his father gave him as a child by introducing him to different people and how he developed an appreciation for the "wisdom of the people."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#-. Written on reel: "ERW," "Children's songs". No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eric Warner Johnson describes his beliefs in the freedom of conscience, in the brotherhood of humanity, in the importance of living one's faith in practical action, and in the value of speaking the truth, even at personal risk. This episode is a rebroadcast of an earlier airing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Waino K. Latvala, a Finnish-American, describes his experiences as an information officer fighting for Finland during the Finnish War, and how he believes that fear is a catalyst to action.

did.unittitle: The Courage to Change the Things I Can

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harry McAlpin describes his belief in the importance of justice and equality, and the challenges of living that creed as an African American in America.

did.unittitle: The Way to Happiness, Understanding and Peace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wilson Compton describes the influence of his Presbyterian parents on his beliefs (including his mother's child-rearing philosophy of "The Bible, soap, and spinach"), and he explains how the Golden Rule is a concept found in all of the major world religions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#-. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Mardikian describes his Armenian custom of serving the staff of his restaurant on Christmas Day, his imprisonment and escape from Armenia, and the welcome and success he found in America.

Immigrants
Altruism
Hope
Success
Work
Prejudices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harlan Cleveland describes his beliefs as "ideas that Im willing to do something about" and recounts the satisfaction he derives from helping others achieve basic needs such as justice, security, and a sense of achievement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jean Hersholt describes his belief that human relationships are "problems of arithmetic"--where there are few people, individuals realize their responsibility to help their neighbors, but in crowded areas, the responsibility is passed along to someone else--and he notes that the world would be a better place if people remembered that they were in fact neighbors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jacob Bronowski describes his simultaneous introduction to mathematics and the English language, his love that developed for both subjects, and his belief in using the mind to find truth.

Truth

Respect
Art
Science
Language acquisition
