scopecontent.p: Laurence Sharples describes the essential beliefs he tries to live by; keep active and busy, educate his heart and have empathy, remain honest, and create something positive to leave behind.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Susan Savage talks about the impact the death of her mother had on her and her beliefs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monroe Deustch expresses his belief that the sentiment of brotherhood between people could solve many of the world's problems and also expresses his belief that there is a greater power in the world that has created the Universe and that this power is immortal just as the spirit of people is immortal as well.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Allman explains why losing his sight endowed him with an appreciation for life and how he learned to believe in himself and adapt and adjust to reality.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harold Taylor expresses his beliefe in the essential goodness of people and their natures and describes his philosophy that that, quality of life and faith in the future is a consequence of developing this goodness to live in harmony with other people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Daryl Zanuck explains that the virtues he learned in his boyhood in Nebraska, charity and loyalty, are still the fundamental virtues that are most important in his life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Genevieve B. Earle remembers the surprise of seeing poverty as a child and how she developed a belief in the benefits of a strong government to promote laws and provide for its citizens although she says that can only happen when the people are engaged as active, equal partners in the work of a city.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elon Borton envies his fathers unwavering faith in God and explains his own evolving faith in God; that He has a plan and a purpose for everyone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Susie Jones believes spiritual fulfillment comes from attending to the mundane chores of daily life and describes her belief in the fundamental goodness of people her desrie to be one with God.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bennet Schauffler talks about the importance of keeping active in order to find happiness, that if one enjoys what one is doing and works at it one has no time, or inclination, to argue or fight with others. boredom and inactivity have led people to conflict and materialistic greed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Louis Trilling talks about how beliefs change, particularly as one changes, and what is important is that one does have beliefs to follow and that for one to be happy and content one should believe in something outside of oneself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: R.Gopolakrishnan describes his awareness, upon coming to America, that the beliefs and dreams of Americans are the same as those of the people of India and that the desire for peace, liberty, brotherhood and cooperation are not limited by national borders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Virginia Sale believes that to have a succesful and happy life it is important to do good for others in all things and to do this she tries to remember to act always as one of God's children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bob Evans explains his belief in the individual and the individual's responsibility to oneself, to one's community, and to one's God, emphasizing the importance of equality, self respect and the Ten Commandments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: James Du Pont explains his belief that life is difficult but people are strong, although complicated by being both good and bad, and to be good one must be humble, compassionate and have faith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradford Smith describes his fascination with the universe and its creation and the importance of creativity in life, bith in general and in a person's life, and that one must develop this creativity through social connections, democracy and love.

did.unittitle: You Have to Water the Plant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leland Stowe talks about his experiences around the world meeting different people and the similarities he saw and how his expereinces convinced him that everyone should try to undestand other people and act with comapsiion and empathy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Totton describes the meaning he finds in life as a result of his religious faith and belief that God works through man which encourages and enables him to support and aid others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bonaro Overstreet talks about her doubt and her one certain belief, that we must all act towards one another with good will and kindness because people are intimately connected and the notion of individuality is a misperception.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reverend Irvin Underhill believes that good things can come out of adversity when one keeps faith and he recalls an experience in Africa in which fear and danger led him to peace and tranquility.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Althea Hottel remembers an influential poem and advice from her grandmother and how these things have shaped her and impacted her experience in life and religion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harold Stassen describes Albert Schweitzer's life and his philosophy of "reverance for life," and from this explains why people yearn for freedom and dictatorships can never stop this yearning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anne Eristoff does not believe the concept of Hell should be a motivating factor for good behavior but rather believes that incentive should come from wanting to be a part of the natural harmony of the world through goodness, truth and beauty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edwin Lukas speaks about the importance of tolerance and respect for other people, cultures and races and the negative impact prejudice can have on an individual and a community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Richie mentions a social experiment he tried in which he behaved selfishly one week and selflessly the following, what he discovered is that he felt better when acting selflessly and he believes now that good deeds can only be accomplished through good means.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 113132 [on a side of box, small white sticker with black inverted T, meaning unknown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anne Donaldson describes her beliefs in the loving Fatherhood of God, the brotherhood of humanity, the triumph of good over evil, and the development of God's Kingdom through the efforts of individuals working with God's help for social reform.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nicholas Norton describes his belief that beauty is the basic tenant which makes his life feel secure, that religion ought to lead to a feeling of beauty, and that he would be willing to fight and die to prevent oppression and preserve freedom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Koegler, Executive Vice President of Doehler-Jarvis, describes how he was forced to accept responsibility at an early age because of the death of his father, and how he came to view responsibility as a privilege rather than an obligation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edgar Scott describes his beliefs that the universe was created by God, that God is loving and in control of events, that the existence of evil does not negate the existence of God but rather teaches us important life lessons, that what happens after death is still an "unsolved puzzle," and that individuals must surrender to the things in life which are too big for them to dominate.

did.unittitle: Man Is Like a Fruit Tree

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elmer Bobst, President of Warner-Hudnut Incorporated, describes his 82-year-old friend Bernard Baruch, and describes his belief that long life and happiness are achieved through the act of remaining productive, even after retirement.

did.unittitle: I Was Meant to Be Something

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Margery Brown describes her beliefs in God, in the existence of a soul, in the satisfaction of contributing to life, and in the value of humility.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nelson Glueck, president of Hebrew Union College, Jewish Institute of Religion, recounts an experience in which he tried but failed to out-pedal a rain storm while cycling through the countryside, and describes how this experience helped form his belief that he should never try to run from difficult life circumstances.

controlaccess.subject: Metaphor
Cycling
Rain and rainfall
Fortitude
Happiness
controlaccess.corpname: Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 114111 [side cover includes small white sticker, with black bar, meaning unknown]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Founder and Executive Director of the National Committee on Alcoholism, Marty Mann describes her experience with alcoholism, and states her beliefs that suffering is universal but can be used to teach life lessons and that she is uniquely suited to help the suffering of alcoholics.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Joubert de la Ferte, Philip, Sir

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sir Philip Joubert, Director of Public Relations in the Air Ministry, describes his beliefs in the goodness of humans, in the importance of self-sacrifice and duty, and in the uncertainty of believing in the simple faith of the past.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#114111 [little white sticker with black bar on side, meaning unknown]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gillie Potter states his belief in the power of wit and "foolishness" to communicate truth, and describes his belief that his task is to bring merriness back to a modern zeitgeist that is currently devoid of humor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ward Greene charts a timeline of faith through an individual's lifetime--accepting as a child, intense as a young adult, and uncertain in middle age--and describes his beliefs in simple truths such as the Golden Rule.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: L.A. Pittenger, president emeritus of Ball State University's Teacher College, describes how his faith was challenged by tragedies and illness, but ultimately strengthened, and he states his beliefs in a creator, in the ultimate order of events, in the thereaputic effects of nature, in the importance of the family, and in the necessity of repaying one's community with service.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Astor, Nancy Witcher Langhorne Astor, Viscountess

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Viscountess Astor recounts growing up in Virginia and being influenced by the faith of her African American nurse, and states her belief that the English-speaking people are the hope of the world because the Bible has been translated into their common language, that individuals don't start life on an equal plane because of socioeconomic disadvantages, that one needs the doctrine of the fatherhood of God in order to believe in the brotherhood of humanity, that Mary Eddy Baker's vision has brought healing, and that Christ's message will bring peace on Earth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roger Williams describes his belief that the modern age needs to balance its achievements in science and technology with wisdom and the foresight to anticipate the impact that innovations will have upon daily living.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 115568 [little white sticker with black bar on side - meaning unknown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clyde Hoey, former North Carolina U.S. Senator and Governor, describes how his faith in God helped him to overcome childhood fears of walking home in the dark, and supported him through life's challenges, a happy marriage, and the death of his spouse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe Mickle, President of the Centenary College of Louisiana, describes his enthusiasm for life and his gratitude for the sacrifices of previous generations, and states his belief that gratitude is linked to action, i.e., that an individual who is grateful lives to please God.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cecil Day Lewis, Chair of Poetry at Oxford University, describes faith as the core of an individual's being, and states his faith (defined thusly) as the creation of poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#115568 [incomplete, do not use]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carl Byers, Superintendent of Parma City Schools, describes his beliefs in using intelligent change to create an optimistic future and in living his life in a way that makes others happy to see him come rather than glad to see him go.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lt. Col. George Stewart, Air Force Interpreter of American Life and Culture to the British Armed Forces, describes how he developed a moral code based on friendliness, and explains how his faith in people developed because of his neighbors' friendliness, and how Jesus demonstrated God's friendliness during His time on earth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#115567 [front cover, handwritten note: TIB Reel 8]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mary Belden, president and treasurer of Belden Frosting Company, describes her beliefs in the brotherhood of individuals, the need for tolerance, the importance of listening to the other side of an argument, the dignity of human beings, the need to remember the past, and her confidence that Christianity will triumph over other philosophies, dispelling fear and uncertainty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Joyce, founder of Joyce Incorporated, Shoe Manufacturers, describes how the deaths of his brother and son led him to conclude that he could only have faith in God's purposes rather than demand an explanation of His actions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Andrew Holmstrom, Mayor of Worcester, MA and Vice President of the Norton Company, describes being raised by Swedish-born parents, recites a Swedish prayer and its English translation, and describes how he has passed that heritage of faith and traditions to his own children and grandchildren.

did.unittitle: I Dont Play to the Grandstand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bobby Doerr, second baseman for the Boston Red Sox, describes his belief that it is better to help his teammates through simple actions than to make a flashy play that only causes problems for the team.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Magnus Kristoffersen describes how reading has shaped his life, and describes the lessons he has derived from stories: from Sutton Vane's Outward Bound, he has learned that he must give a final account of his actions, and from Selma Lagerlof's Jerusalem, he has learned that trying to save one's life at the expense of others merely backfires in the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joshua Lea describes his beliefs (based on the book of Ecclesiastes) that an afterlife would be a surprise but not an unpleasant one; that humanity is not inherantly sinful, but only its inventions; that liberty is essential to allow individuals to live by their own decisions; and that it is his responsibility to exercise his intellect, curiosity, and reason.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Headmaster of St. Paul Academy, John DeQuedville Briggs describes his beliefs in honesty, trustworthiness, and the Golden Rule; and explains how his experience of other people living by these beliefs provides him hope for the future, despite the prevailing spirit of pessimism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harry Schacter, president of the Kaufman-Straus Company, describes his belief in fighting for social justice: though one individual might not make a difference, he still has a right to choose the side upon which he fights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 115567 [incomplete]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ohio state senator Catherine Dobbs describes her beliefs that the Golden Rule teaches her how to live life, that nature's laws underlie the basic circumstances of life, that individuals are created in the image of God, that human nature is capable of great kindness and great cruelty, and that personal freedom is a right which comes from God.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Galen Jones, an official in the Office of Education of the Federal Security Agency, describes his belief in the digity of human personality, in the existence of free will, and in the responsibility of individuals to make their own choices in life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Higginbotham, president of the Consolidation Coal Company, describes his "principle of kindness" (a resolve to avoid hurting others), his "principle of self-analysis" (a process of self-reflection which determines personal faults and ways in which to overcome them), and his "principle of tolerance" (a belief that because God is compassionate and forgiving, he should be as well).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Laura Crandon of the Horace Mann School for the Deaf states her belief that the world's problems could be addressed if individuals viewed humanity as an interconnected society in which each individual has a part to play.

controlaccess.subject: Progress
Social problems
Humanity
Responsibility
Self-actualization (Psychology)
controlaccess.corpname: Horace Mann School for the Deaf (Allston, Mass.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leonard Simons describes his beliefs that satisfaction comes from helping others, that the list of charitable organizations he has helped is just as important as his list of paying clients, that he is fortunate to live a useful life, that any money beyond what is needed for his family's security is devoted to helping others, and that serving others is troublesome, but a source of fun, as well.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martin Littleton describes an experience in which he flunked a college exam rather than give in to the temptation to cheat, and how that lesson in integrity provided the framework for living a life of personal, inner satisfaction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elizabeth Coker describes how an accident left her face disfigured, and the how the process of exerting extra effort to overcome her self-consciousness developed a love for people, a respect for tolerance, and a joy in laughter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 115818 [front cover handwritten note: "This 1 Reel (2)]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#116096 [small white sticker with black bar, meaning unknown]

did.unittitle: Turning a Valley of Tears into Paradise

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Maria Trapp describes how she and her husband attempted to understand the Gospels' instructions to "become like little children"; and, observing their own children, came to the conclusion that children live whole-heartedly in the present without worrying about the past or future.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Sinclair, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, describes his belief that faith in an immortal soul, prayer, knowledge of the truth, and humility will help him overcome discouragement, cynicism, and the fear of death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poetry editor of The American Friend, E. Merrill Root describes an experience of crossing the Atlantic under threat of submarine attack, and realizing, in the midst of fear, that life contains incredible beauty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Julie Adams (also called Julia Adams) describes her decision to pursue acting, and the small inner voice that guides her through disappointments, criticism, failures, and success.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 116097 [little white sticker on side with black bar - meaning unknown]. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: H.C. Carlson, director of Men's Student Health Service and Varsity Basketball Coach at the University of Pittsburgh, describes the rewards he experiences through serving others and accomplishing simple tasks, and states his belief that the people with whom he comes into contact deserve the best he has to offer them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roger Ansell, associate editor of Holiday Magazine, describes his belief in the need for skepticism rather than arrogant certainty, in his hope that civilization will advance through the current anxious age, in the importance of seeing society's maturation as a point yet to come in the future, in the realization of the humanity of others, and in the refreshing openness of children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fran Warren describes the start of her career as a professional singer, her belief that people are instinctively nice, her gratitude for her faithful fans, and the responsibility she feels as a celebrity in the public eye.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lord Kemsley describes his beliefs in the importance of family life, home-made entertainment, and self-reliance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 116097 [backside stamp: (smudged) 89913]. No date is available for this reel.

did.unittitle: Love and the Unceasing Wonder of Life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mr. and Mrs. Hale, having been married for a long time, talk of the imminent death that will separate them as they age, and inspite of the expected grief they will continue to see life with excitement and wonder, and remind all of the importance to have compassion for everyone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vern Knudsen, Dean of the graduate division at UCLA, explains uses his work in acoustics and science as the basis for his belief in the importance of honesty, truth, and integrity to live a good, happy life, and also provides an example from the field of acoustics to demonstrate his point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signe Hasso tells the parable of a painter attempting to create his masterpiece to describe her belief in the importance of refraining from judgement since it is impossible to know and understand the complicated events that bring a person to any moment or place in their life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Werner Herbert, Head of Werner Textile Consultants, would like to add an eleventh commandment; to be kind to everyone. He also explains why kindess is important and how followinf this commandment has positively affected his life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 116098 [on side of box, little white sticker with black bar - meaning unknown]. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sir Gerald Barry, Director General of the Festival of Britain, talks about the changes in the world after World War II, his relationship to christianity and his belief that there is no life after death and so one must appreciate and live one's own life to the fullest extent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ralph Strebel, Academic dean of Utica College, talks about his early childhood and his awareness of class and his youthful epiphany that one should have pride in oneself for who they are, not where they come from, and how this realization supports his belief in equality and democracy. He also talks about the need to develop a more spiritual philosophy in the world and abandon the materialistic philosophy that he believes is pervasive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ned Dearborn, president of the National Safety Council and former dean of the Division of General Education at New York University, talks about the importance of faith in overcoming adversity and describes the many things in which he places faith, such as religion, the goodness of people, himself, and he concludes by describing his faith in faith itself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joseph Szigeti describes his efforts to avoid being stereotyped and remaining authentic to himself and also the obligation one has to work with and help other people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edith Nelson talks about learning the Golden rule early in life, the impact teaching has had on her life and the importance of kindness, friends and families when struggling through adversity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arthur Dodineau, superintendent of Detroit Public Schools, talks about the foundational experiences he had as a boy growing up on a farm in rural Michigan, and his faith in teachers, religion and the future of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mary Draper, a meber on the boards of Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service, Children's Aid Society, and Long Island University Hospital, describes her belief in equality and change as a positive force in the world and peoples lives, positive change she has seen in people through her work and she hopes for changes in the world that will bring peace and progress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and former dean and trustee of the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania, explains his belief that we all perceive the world differently and so we need to try to approach one another with empathy, respect, and compassion, and that this attitude is particularly important in the American business world where people spend such a great deal of time and attention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# (missing)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Cleland, head of the Research Group of the Huntington Library, describes a time in his life in which he was distraught and took a trip along the Colorado river with friends. The beauty he saw during the trip, Robert Cleland says, reinspired his life and faith.

controlaccess.subject: Anxiety
Depression, Mental
Beauty
Nature
Faith
Peace
controlaccess.corpname: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jay Kennedy speaks of growing up as a young, homeless orphan and the important lesson of survival, and staying alive, that he learned and still lives by, although tempered by the knowledge that to fully develop one must do so within the context of reltionships with others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marie Neal-Martin, Editor and publisher of the Western Reserve Democrat, describes how she inherited from her mother and grandmother her beliefs in people, the Golden Rule, her country, and God by describing her mother's attitude in adversity and her grandmother's life after the Civil War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: CBS quizmaster Bob Hawk belives in humility and like Charles Lamb he likes to do good deeds without taking credit. However, he also describes some of the satisfaction he takes from doing good deeds and posits that a little selfishness is not a bad thing when done for the right reasons, what he calls "selfish humility."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# (missing)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: C. Jared Ingersoll, Director of the Pennsylvania Railway, describes the tragic loss of his wife and son and how he persevered through tragedy to find happiness in life again as a result of his faith and belief in an afterlife and the value and enjoyment he finds from being kind and generous. This episode is a rebroadcast of an earlier airing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Phyllis Parker is reminded of a saying she was fond of as a child, "love conquers all" and describes the good and sometimes bad results that have come of love. She also compares love to electricity, a flow of energy, and says that if we could all harness love and direct it wisely the world could be a much better place without prejudice. In addition, this essay contains an advertisement for a This I Believe LP album.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Lyon, P. H. B. (Percy Hugh Beverley)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hugh Lyon, former Headmaster of Rugby School, talks about God and man and explains that the noble qualities of man, such as love, and vlaor and heroism, prove that he must be the children of God, and God gives life meaning and purpose. In addition, this essay contains an advertisement for a This I Believe LP album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# (missing)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holgar Johnson, President of the Institute of Life Insurance, explains the importance of adapting to change for progress, and lists some of his beliefs such as: faith in honesty of people, respect for people, the importance of compassion, taking action for one's self, and the belief in a higher power. This essay also contains an advertisement for a This I Believe LP album.

controlaccess.subject: Anxiety
Change
Human beings
Adaptability (Psychology)
Honesty
Respect for Persons
Self-actualization (Psychology)
Self-culture
Love
Progress
God
Immaterialism
controlaccess.corpname: Institute of Life Insurance (New York, N.Y.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stan Kenton is concerned with the development of humanity and he describes the need for growth and change for positive development to progress in all aspects of a person's life and also explains that everyone participates and contributes something to the development of humanity and his contributions and own developments are through music. This essay also contains an advertisement for a This I Believe LP album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Raymond Allen, Chancellor of UCLA, describes the impact his family had on teaching him responsibility and other beliefs such as the necessity of family and describes the beliefs he holds close, such as the importance of kindness,the perfectabiloity of man, the need for faith and freedom to worship, and the value of creativity. This essay also contains an advertisement for a This I Believe LP album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Turner, 37th Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, compares life to a navigation in that everyone begins life in a specific spot and situation and the travels toward an unkown destination, using what ever tools we have acquired in life to give direction; from this he adds that it is important to keep your awareness in the present and do the task at hand. This essay also contains an advertisement for a This I Believe LP album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# (missing) [front cover includes "Empty Box" sticker]. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harry Dietrich describes how his family background, his teachers, and the tools and techniques invented by doctors of previous generations have all equipped him to achieve healing more effectively than ever before, and his belief that his responsibility is to help dispel fear in his patients.

controlaccess.subject: Fear
Patients
Medical instruments and apparatus
Medical innovations
Responsibility
controlaccess.corpname: Beverly Hills Clinic; University of California, Los Angeles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Norman Angell describes his belief that evil will triumph over good in society unless indviduals recognize their own personal capacity for evil and strive to overcome this tendency through self-discipline.

controlaccess.subject: Religious tolerance
Self-control
Good and evil
Reason
controlaccess.corpname: Parliament of the United Kingdom (House of Commons)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dwight Taylor describes his belief that science cannot answer the question of "Why?" and that, until individuals learn to live in gratitude and wonder at the miracle of life, humans will not learn to live peacefully with one another.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Drake describes his belief that life is like a tight-rope act he witnessed as a child: that individuals are constantly wavering between good and evil in an upward fight against gravity, but ultimately good will win.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 118431 [side of box includes small white sticker with two black bars -meaning unknown; cover of box includes "Empty Box" sticker]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe McNeil describes his beliefs in a God who created and watches over the universe, and in the power of preparing youth to impact their communities in tangible ways, no matter how seemingly small or insignificant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Norman Cousins describes his beliefs in both the individuality of the self and the unity of all humanity, as well as in a moral order derived from universal order; therefore, the poverty of others impacts his own condition, and he works to alleviate social problems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clement Reicher recounts a short allegory he wrote as a child which formed the basis for his belief that love must be personal (not idea-driven) and unpossessive, in order to increase and lead ultimately to happiness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Houghton describes his childhood experiences of visiting his grandparents' Quaker meetings, and how those experiences led to a belief in an inner voice which provides moral direction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 118431 [on side of box, small white sticker with two black bars - meaning unknown; cover includes a sticker "Empty Box"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Viola Livingston describes the influence her grandmother had on her beliefs in courage, faith, integrity, honor, service, and love of others; and she explains how these beliefs influenced her decision to go to Korea with the Department of the Army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lord Vansittart describes his belief that there is no compromise possible between good and evil, and that an individual must make a stand against evil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Helen Winston describes her experiences of trying to become an actress--working as a waitress in order to study people--and states her beliefs that there is a little bit of godliness in every person, that individuals have a basic impulse towards virtue, and that it is important to value the beauty and love available in the present moment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 118686 [Original box includes sticker "Empty Box"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Arthur Seymour describes her belief in the power of offering friendship to lonely women, and her attempts to do so.

controlaccess.subject: Female friendship
Interpersonal relations
Social Networks
Altruism
Loneliness
controlaccess.corpname: Federation of Women's Clubs of Greater Cleveland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sir Evelyn Wrench describes how an encounter with extreme poverty shook his faith in God, and how an experience at the funeral service of King Edward VII restored that faith, as he became more inclusive in his beliefs and practices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 118686. [Original box includes sticker "Empty Box"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Maxwell-Fyfe describes his beliefs in the faith of a romantic--a faith with the conviction and idealism to address the problems of the age and which recognizes humanity's need for spiritual advancement, in addition to scientific and material advancement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Howard Spalding describes his belief in a divine spark that exists within every person and which spurs creative invention and moral reasoning, and states his belief that happiness is achieved through the ability to use creative intelligence in the service of others.

did.unittitle: My Faith Is Like a Circle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anne Rombeau describes her belief in the unity of nature and humanity, with each piece contributing as it freely chooses, and recounts an experience in which she overcame a physical ailment to continue her life of travel and flying. This episode is a rebroadcast of an earlier airing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 118686 [original box included sticker "Empty Box"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Florence Bartlett describes how her belief in the unity of humanity developed during an encounter with Bedouins in the Sahara desert, and explains her decision to create a museum of folk art, which expresses that bond of unity between peoples.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hilda Yoder describes how she used to emphasize marriage and financial security, only to lose both her husband and home; she describes how she found purpose and healing in serving others; and she states her beliefs in virtues of kindness, forgiveness, simplicity, and humilty that are still practiced by children (and should be practiced by adults).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edith Sams describes how a childhood encounter with a handicapped individual inspired her to enter social work as a career, and her belief that the efforts of individuals can make an impact on the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Muhamma Farid Abu Hadid describes how he struggled to understand the meaning of life, until he realized that happiness was achievable only by stripping away constructed appearances and pursuing affection, cooperation, goodness, mercy, and justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 118686 [original box included sticker "Empty Box"]. Patent No. 2,571,133. Reel not digitized.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# 119247 Series II Side 2 [Original box includes sticker "Empty Box"]. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Dobie describes his belief in those things that make him "feel big": he believes in a supreme Being, the value of questioning to avoid blind faith, and the importance of eliminating prejudice. This episode is a rebroadcast of an earlier airing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carlos Romulo describes his belief in being true to himself despite the cost, exemplified by his inability to be with his family while he operated the broadcast Voice of Freedom during WWII and in his decision to withdraw his candidacy for president of the Philippines in order to help a candidate who shared his values win the election.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ella Mae Howey states her belief in a personal, loving God who provides abundant life opportunities, and describes how learning to manage her condition of hearing loss taught her to believe in her power to respond positively to life's challenges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Landon describes his belief in the ability of people to achieve monumental progress for society, and in the need to maintain a grasp of spiritual and moral truths in the midst of that progress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#119247 Series II Side 3 Incomplete; See ET9 [Original box includes sticker "Empty Box"]. No date is available for this reel.

did.unittitle: Free Minds and Hearts at Work

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jackie Robinson describes his emotional response to the integration of baseball, and states his belief that humans can and must work to overcome prejudice and dogma.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Julius Stulman states his belief in the need for self-evaluation and describes his own practice of speculating on what values the future might require and subsequently living his life towards achieving those goals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lord Beveridge states his belief in "vicarious immortality" and in the value both in leaving a legacy of virtue and in following the legacy left by Christ the man.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#119429 Series 12, Side 8 [sticker on original front of box states "Empty Box"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job#119429. Series 12, Side 11. [sticker on original front of box marked "Empty Box"]. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Carlson, president of the State University of New York, describes how his experience of living with an Inuit family in Greenland disproved his belief of belonging to a superior race, and states his beliefs in the brotherhood of humanity, the virtue of patience, the need of self-evaluation, the unity of family, and the method of science. Contains a short advertisement for This I Believe book (this essay included in the book).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Raymond Swing, an editor for "This I Believe," describes how the realization that most of his troubles were caused by ignorance led him to become more tolerant of others, and states his beliefs in his participation in the "All-Wisdom" of God, in his responsibility to change himself, and in the importance of extending to others the love and freedom which he desires for himself. Contains a short advertisement for This I Believe book (this essay included in the book).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Noyes describes his belief that the complexity of the world can only be attributed to God, and that the clearest revelation of God can be found by looking at the human soul. Contains a short advertisement for This I Believe book (this essay included in the book).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Cowell describes his belief in music as a medium through which a composer may communicate a humanizing philosophy to others, and states his beliefs in the Golden Rule, equality, indvidualism, freedom, and the responsibility to behave ethically in exchange for participation in society. Contains a short advertisement for This I Believe book (this essay included in the book).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 10" Reel. Job# (missing). [Original box includes sticker marked "Empty Box"]. No date is available for this reel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Louis Miller, director of the Jewish Memorial Hospital in New York City, remembers the important lesson he learned from his mother, to always help those in need, and describes how this led him to a career in hospital administration.

did.unittitle: The Essence of Religion on Earth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jonathan Daniels, editor of the News and Observer, relates a story from his religious upbrining about the remarkable testimonials told in his religious community and explains that equality of all men before God is what drew him to the Episcopalian Church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Irene Adler, Senior in the College of Home Economic at Cornell University, discusses the importance of faith in her personal life and in society and explains why it gives her self-confidence to succeed and also why it enables people to work together in society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roger Phillips, publisher of World Magazine, describes the faith and values he inherited from his family and explains the value and influence of a mate and examines the many elements that make up a persons heritage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 14 10" audiotape reels of Murrow's reports during his CBS years.

News Reports, World War II (7" Audiotape Reels)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 18 (7") audiotape reels of Murrow's war reports during World War II, from 1939-45.

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reel No. 1 - 1939: According to accompanying index, reel contains the following. 'Personal Greetings from Professor Milo Ryan, on behalf of the University of Washington (Seattle), to Mr. Edward R. Murrow.
1939: Sept 3 - N. Chamberlain: "speaks from No. 10 Downing Street; 'Britain is now at war with Germany;' announcement of war plans."
1939: Sept 3 - E.R.M.: "2-hr. ultimatum to Germany unanswered; Chamberlain declares war; air raid sirens sounded but no planes appear."

1939: Sept 11 - "E.R.M.: "Britain not surprised by Canada's entry into war; press asks 'What kind of war is this?;' Russian position unknown."(handwritten note included in box reads: 'Britain defines its aims')
1939: Sept 14 - (E. R. M.): "R.A.F. Eyewitness report of Kiel canal bombing; notes on home front; increased activity in Russia."
1939: Sept 29 - "E.R.M.: "Describes British airfield; R.A.F. hits at Germany." (handwritten note included in box also reads: 'Sept. 29th English countryside')
7 1/2 ips; one track.

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten note reads: Wool against blue cloth; Oct 21 - First Aid battle - Everything is possible but nothing is likely; Oct. 24 - British Radio and TV - what Brit. reading.' (7-1/2 ips; one track)

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reel No. 3 - 1939:

Nov. 15: E.R.M. Commons secret sessions proposal rejected; British economic problems; Gracie Fields entertains at front; Nov. 19: E.R.M. British press speculates on fall of Hitler; describes Brit. military bases atmosphere; Nov. 28: E.R.M. New sessions of Commons; Butter scarce; Are British/French fighting U.S.s battle?; Dec. 4: E.R.M. British steamer sunk; Brit. to seize German export; 3% Brit. men are conscientious objectors; hearings described; Dec. 11: E.R.M. Broadcasting from train in tunnel; Dec. 23: E.R.M. Western Front quiet; introduces Brit. mother in message to children evacuated; re: need of state socialism in Britain.
[unknown source for content of this note] (7-1/2 ips; one track)

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 5

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reel No. 6 - 1941:

Jan. 29: E.R.M. (Manchester) : Describes trip from Belfast. Mar. 9: E.R.M. Describes British under air attack; Mar. 30: E.R.M. French convoy in Span. water; Describes visit to anti-aircraft factory; June 1: E.R.M. Brit. war office report on fall of Crete; first U.S. food ship arrives; Brit. re European shipping; Luftwaffe over London; June 21: E.R.M. R.A.F. activities; Russian/Germ. speculation decreases odds against war there.
[unknown source for content of this note] (7-1/2 ips; one track)

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reel No. 7- 1941: June 22: W. Churchill: Speaks of Hitlers attack on Russia this morning; says he warned Stalin; Hitler launching a cataract upon mankind; We shall fight him on land, sea, air; promises whatever help possible to Russia; (Followed by comment by Messrs. E.R. Murrow and Elmer Davis (New York)); July 13: E.R.M. Russia/Britain sign agreement for mutual assistance; Germ. confident of success in Russia; British air offensive stepped up; Aug. 14: E.R.M. Roosevelt-Churchill meeting.
[unknown source for content of this note] (7-1/2 ips; one track)

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 8

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1942: Feb. 1: E.R.M. from Minneapolis; Brit. will invade Continent when we there to help; discusses bombing of Germany. [unknown source for content of this note]

(7-1/2 ips; one track) Handwritten note in reel box reads Nov. 9 [1941] Remembers events up to then- can we get better quality?. This is last time hell be talking to you for three months air raid warden who lost hand shell shocked boy-

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reel No. 10- 1942: Sept. 2: E.R.M. (Three Years of War) Reviews the role of the British in the war;
1944: Apr. 20: E.R.M. Details bombing of France and Germany; June 5: E.R.M. French coast blanket bombed; German propaganda desperate. [unknown source for content of this note]
(7-1/2 ips; one track)

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II - Reel No. 4 [a]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original reel box is labeled Tape number 4 but there is already a number 4 in this series. The [a] is to differentiate this reel from the first number 4 reel. Returned in fall 2008 by a researcher and thus cataloged out of order.

Original box reads: "Tape No. 4 Edward R. Murrow. Cut 1 Sept 8 1940 - 1466 (Good); Cut 2 September 9 1940 - 1469 (Excellend); last half Cut 3 September 10 1940 - 1470 (Good endpiece); Cut 4 September 11 1940 - 1471 (Good open); first 60 seconds Cut 5 September 12 1940 - 1472 (Excellent open).
Original reel box preserved: Scotch Magnetic Tape 311 Tenzar Backing, 1200 Feet, splice free.

did.unittitle: News Reports, World War II Reel No. 9

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (7 1/2 ips; single track). Reel box reads: Scotch recording tape, Tartan Series, All purpose, 1.5 Mil Acetate, 1200 Reet, splice free, 7# reel, stereo quality for finest recording; has exclusive life-time silicone lubrication (.635 cm x 364 m) 141.
Original reel box preserved in same box as reel. Returned in fall 2008 by a researcher and thus cataloged out of order.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 3 papers related to the audio visual materials in the Edward R. Murrow Collection.

scopecontent.p: Consists of papers related to the World War II Reels (Subseries 005.011) and the Voice of America Reels (Subseries 005.009)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contain the awards, certificates, diplomas, gifts, academic hoods, and honorary degrees given to Edward R. Murrow during his career in journalism and broadcasting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of the memorabilia displayed in the Murrow Room at Fletcher. Memorabilia held there includes awards, certificates, diplomas, gifts, academic hoods, and honorary degrees given to Edward R. Murrow during his career in journalism and broadcasting.
The academic hoods, item numbers 00108-00120, were removed from this series in February 2008 and moved to subseries MS025/006.003 (Awards - Honorary Degrees and Honorary Titles).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: [Organization] __[Arrangement]The Murrow Room cases are numbered 1-24, starting with the first case on the right side of the door and continuing counterclockwise around the room. Shelves in each case are designated with letters, the top shelf being shelf A, the next shelf B, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 13"H x 3 1/2"W x 3 1/2"L. Trophy with square marble base and bronze figure wearing cape and holding up a wreath and scroll. Engraving reads, "Air Force Association Award Presented to Edward R. Murrow For Distinguished Service to Airpower in the Field of Arts and Letters 1952." Okay condition, needs to be cleaned. Murrow Room case 18, shelf A (right).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 17 1/4"H x 12"W. Certificate presented by the United States Commander, Berlin (Albert Watson) to Edward R. Murrow for venturing behind the Iron Curtain and supporting the resistance to communism. Color certificate in black wood frame. Wire on back for hanging. A facsimile copy of "Guardian of Berlin's Freedom," created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original document is located at the Digital Collections and Archives in MS025.006.003.002.00042 box number: 39090011518343y. Murrow Room case 9, shelf A.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 13 3/4"H x 13 3/4"W. Black and white photo of E.R. Murrow holding cigarette. Photo signed in upper right hand corner by photographer Cecil Beaton (on the back of the image). White mat with black frame. A facsimile copy of this image, created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original image is located at the Digital Collections and Archives in MS025.006.003.003.00013 box number: 39090011537780y.

did.unittitle: Admiral of the Flagship Fleet Award from American Airlines

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 18 1/2"H x 14"W. Black and white certificate with red, white and blue ribbon on bottom. In black frame. Water marks on upper right hand corner. Murrow Room case 23, shelf F (right).

did.unittitle: Case for U.S. Navy medal, pins, and buttons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Blue plastic case with clear lid. Blue velvet lining with baize border. Murrow Room case 4, shelf F (left).

did.unittitle: National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Club, Inc. Annual Radio Award

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 9 3/4"H x 12 3/4"W. Award for best presentation of current foreign policy issues. Black and white certificate in black frame. Framed by I. Ballin's Son Artistic Picture Framing, New York, NY. A facsimile copy of " National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Club, Inc. Annual Radio Award, July 1, 1953," created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original document is located at the Digital Collections and Archives in MS025.006.003.003.00005 box number: 39090011537780y. Murrow Room case 24, shelf B (left) (original in 39090011537780y).

did.unittitle: Charcoal portrait of Edward R. Murrow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 22 1/2"H x 18"W. Charcoal drawing by the artist. Gray mat and frame. This a facsimile of a charcoal image published in Reader's Digest by Uri Oberhardt. According to the artist's letter located in MS025.001.001.003.00012, he sent Edward R. Murrow the facsimile reproduction in 1950. Mr. Oberhardt wrote a dedication at the bottom "To Edward Murrow with the compliments of Uri Oberhardt 1950." A facsimile copy of this image, created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original image is located in the Digital Collections and Archives MS025.006.003.002.00045 box number: 39090011518343y. Murrow Room case 13, shelf B (left).

did.unittitle: Portrait of Edward R. Murrow, for Time magazine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 16"W x 21"H. Color portrait of Murrow by Guy Rowe (GIRO). Framed in black and gold frame with linen matte. Tag on back indicates portrait was on display at the National Portrait Gallery, exhibition entitled "On The Air," October 7, 1988 - January 2, 1989. A facsimile copy of this image, created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original image is located in the Digital Collections and Archives MS025.006.003.002.00043 box number: 39090011518343y. Murrow Room case 12, shelf A (original in 39090011518343y).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 12 3/4"W x 18"H. Sketch of Edward R. Murrow. Framed in gold wooden frame. Signed by artist. Backing held together with scotch tape. A facsimile copy of this portrait created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original portrait is located at the Digital Collections and Archives in MS025.006.003.002.00040 box number: 39090011518343y. Murrow Room case 11, shelf B (original in 39090011518343y).

did.unittitle: Honorary Knight Commander of the British Empire Award by Elizabeth the Second

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 17 1/4"W x 21 1/2"H. Certificate in black wooden frame trimmed in gold. Backing in poor condition. A facsimile copy of this document created in 2008, is currently on display in the Murrow room in the original frame. The original document is located at the Digital Collections and Archives in MS025.006.003.002.00044 box number: 39090011518343y. There are two medals and a case which were given to Murrow for being a member of the Order of the British Empire, see MS025.006.001.001.00025.1, MS025.006.001.001.00025.2, and MS025.006.001.001.00025.3. Murrow Room case 7, shelf C.

did.unittitle: 'BBC Television Service War Correspondents Return to Europe Ed Murrow' Edward R. Murrow publicity photograph for the BBC's "After the Battle" film series

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On back of photograph: "22.10.59 / BBC Television Service, War Correspondents Return to Europe. Ed Murrow, who since the war has made such an impact on American and British television, opens the BBC-tv film series AFTER THE BATTLE on Wednesday November 18th (9.30 p.m.) in which six well-known radio war correspondents return to the scenes of some of their most famous wartime despatches [sic.]. During this thiry minute film Murrow discusses the tense days of 1940-41 with the Foreign Secretary, Mr. Selwyn Lloyd, Mr. Frank Cousins and Professor D.W. Brogan." Credit: BBC Copyright Photograph, from BBC, Broadcasting House, London, W. 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note by Susanne Belovari, February 13, 2007: these scripts were collated later on, at least as late as Murrow's time at the USIA or even after his death. See here the introduction of the script from February 9, 1951 which talks about Murrow's work for the USIA. Scripts are introduced by an anonymous commentor. Texts were retyped for this compilation: they lack all editing marks by Murrow. Select pages were replaced by inserting pages of different paper quality, lines are replaced by ' ... ' It is impossible to ascertain how closely these retroactive compilations reflect original scripts and what was broadcast on the radio unless one compares each compiled script with original scripts and broadcasts when available. Also included are scripts not aired. Also included are scripts not aired.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note by Susanne Belovari, February 13, 2007: these scripts were collated later on, at least as late as Murrow's time at the USIA or even after his death. See here the introduction of the script from February 9, 1951 which talks about Murrow's work for the USIA. Scripts are introduced by an anonymous commentator. Texts were retyped for this compilation: they lack all editing marks by Murrow. Select pages were replaced by inserting pages of different paper quality, lines are replaced by ' ... ' It is impossible to ascertain how closely these retroactive compilations reflect the original scripts and what was broadcast originally on the radio unless one compares each compiled script with original scripts and broadcasts when available. Also included are scripts not aired. Also included are scripts not aired.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Carl Claudius [pseud]. No. 88 of 2000 privately printed copies. Long inscription on front flyleaf from author: To Edward R. Murrow, A real reporter whom in spite of his socialistic leanings, I greatly admire. His Person to Person interviews should continue for years to come. Perhaps then, some of the smaller ('thinking') people will be able to gain a clearer discernment of some of the knuckle-heads behind the scenes, who in the name of statesmanship, politics, or education may be selling this country a false bill of goods. Then we can give them a good kick in the rump where it belongs. No more frontiers, indeed! Kindest personal regards, Carl Claudius, nee Gordon K. [Danna?], Denver, Colorado. Errata inserted after title page. The date is the copyright date

The role of the art historian / Millard Meiss--7. Art education in the United States / Victor d'Amico, Allen S. Weller--8. The art museum as a community center / Leslie Cheek, Jr.--9. The arts and their interrelations / Thomas Munro--10. Prints / Carl Zigrosser--11. Sculpture / Henry Hope--12. Decorative arts and crafts / David R. Campbell--13. did.unittitle: Dedication of Edward R. Murrow Center
BBC World Service "Great Reporters" (no. 8: Ed Murrow) radio program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this radio broadcast, Barry Carman discusses Murrow's life and career, particularly his World War II reporting in Europe. The program features excerpts from several of Murrow's reports from Europe, including the following: 1940 reports from London during the Blitz; 1938 report from Vienna during the Anschluss; 1944 report from an aircraft during the Battle of Arnhem; a report with G.I.s in Germany; April 15, 1945 report from Buchenwald concentration camp; report on Winston Churchill becoming British Prime Minister; and his farewell broadcast to England upon returning to the U.S. The program also includes descriptions of Murrow by Anthony Wiggins.

did.unittitle: Large medal for "God and the Empire"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dimensions: 4 1/4"H x 2"W. Medal with red ribbon. "For God and the Empire" written around center of medal. Stamped "sterling" on backside. This medal was given to members of the Order of the British Empire, see MS025.006.001.001.00093. Murrow was awarded the Honorary Knight Commander of the British Empire Award by Elizabeth the Second on February 19, 1965. Americans were given the designation of knight commander for services performed for or on behalf of the United
Kingdom. Shares case with smaller medal.

did.unittitle: Assembly of Captive European Nations recognition of Edward R. Murrow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Murrow trail-blazing reporter and commentator eloquent champion of truth foe of tyranny. In posthumous recognition of his proven concern for the communist-enslaved nations of east-central europe and his consistent support of their freedom goal. Assembly of Captive European Nations. Washington, July 21, 1965." Maker: International Bronze Tablet Company,
NY, NY. Piece of paper underneath stand with flag identification.
